definition[0]: relating to how a person or situation seems to be, rather than how it really is
example[0]: The economy and outward appearance of the area have changed considerably.
example[1]: His clenched fist was the only outward sign of his anger.
definition[1]: directed towards the outside or away from a place
definition[2]: leaving a place, rather than arriving in it
example[3]: The outward flow of investment by British multinationals is high in the manufacturing industry.
example[4]: We use the following methods of despatching outward mail.
